ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course helped me develop a better understanding of the economic models and legal principles used to evaluate racial, ethnic, and gender discrimination in various contexts. Professor Jaynes' lecture notes were concise and summarized key concepts from relevant case law and academic literature well.
Legal cases and economics related to discrimination

In many ways, it was very difficult to tell. We did a lot of constitutional analysis, but it often felt very disjointed and disconnected from larger projects about legal, economic, or intellectual history.

really enjoyed course. sometimes he would say it was a seminar but would be lots of lecturing (which I honestly enjoyed since he is an excellent economist and thinker). tough at 9ams to participate in class tho
A greater understanding of economic discrimination in the 1900s

To be completely honest, I did not take away much from this course. I vaguely learned about court cases related to discrimination, disparate impact vs. intent, and amendments/laws dedicated to protecting individuals from discrimination.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The seminar meetings were structured well to facilitate learning throughout the semester. The readings conveyed the material concisely and comprehensively, and the discussion questions offered interesting ways to mull over the material. The written homework assignments did a great job of prompting more thought and reflection on the reading material. I also really enjoyed participating in the mock trial.

Weaknesses: Professor Jaynes lectured for most of the time. Having the opportunity to discuss some of the material more organically would have been helpful!
I enjoyed coming to class and the professors lecture notes were very clear and organized

Ultimately, even though the course dealt with many of the same themes of my other coursework, the level of engagement with some of the themes wasn't as robust as I would have hoped. Students often felt disinterested or felt that they had already studied most of the information in the course.

Strengths: once a week seminar, homework assignments were short but meaningful and allowed us to explore core course concepts 
Weaknesses: class was boring sometimes, lack of class engagement in econometric analysis and very few sense checks during the math heavy classes

Professor Jaynes made clear lecture notes with discussion questions that helped orient the class. He is also clearly passionate about these topics and went out of his way to share anecdotes that made many concepts more personal and interesting. 

That being said, there was little to no discussion in this class. Professor Jaynes spent a long time lecturing and putting things up on the board that proved to eventually be irrelevant. We watched him do a lot of math and then were never assigned problem sets or expected to know that material in any way. It would be a better use of time to facilitate class discussion more consistently. We also strayed far away from the syllabus. Homework assignments were canceled and not rescheduled until the very end of the semester. The writing assignments were not graded like the syllabus said they would be, and we only had one of the two assigned. By the time the credit d deadline arrived (December 10th), we only had three homework grades in, the last from October 7th. That is literally two months without any grades. Moreover, the feedback we received was just a couple of sentences, even if paired with a bad grade. In my first assignment, I received a low B and only a couple of sentences of feedback. It was unclear how to perform well in the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The course is really interdisciplinary in its approach to analyzing discrimination from the perspectives of law and economic theory. The workload of this course was well structured to facilitate student learning.
I think the course's engagement with the issues was insufficient.

Yes! Great senior economics seminar, especially if you want less math and more history! Very important for economics majors to understand the ways in which the economic system has been and continues to be discriminatory.

Not at all. This is the worst class I have taken at Yale. Not only did I learn absolutely nothing, but I spent the entire semester unsure how I was doing in the class and receiving little to no feedback. I would sit there while Jaynes lectured for just shy of two hours about topics that were convoluted, previously covered already, or just random stories. I ended up taking the class for credit because, by the deadline, we had literally three homework grades in. That was roughly 15% of our grade. Moreover, the last graded assignment was from October 7th, and the deadline to credit d was December 10th. 

Even if you are interested in these topics, do not take this class. You will not learn anything, be frustrated with the lack of transparency, have no idea what your grade is, and dread going every week. Not worth it. 

I read the course reviews and thought I would have a different experience. I did not.
